instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP1V8_SUS: What is PP1V8_SUS? PP1V8_SUS is a 1.8v power rail active in a suspend state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message:
This <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> was brought in for a screen and battery replacement; it had no power on issues.

After the screen and battery change up the computer refuses to power on; ammeter switches to 20V successfully but without any power draw; 0.04 amp.

I checked PPBUS itâ€™s there 8.6V or 8.7 something like that.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is there
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is there
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> is missing, I checked it in diode mode and compared the numbers from FlexBV; it was 0.350 on flex while 0.180 on my board;
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is missing of course.

Since this is a very critical issues I replaced <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> (5V creator) and <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR>; diode readings went up to 0.210 (still now) but now the line pulses every 5 seconds..

This is a customers' computer with important data in it and kinda hopeless here.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Check all you've touched in the replacement process.
Broken trace, or knocked off components can happen.

Test the board alone, disconnecting any cable, apart of USB/power flex.
Only 5V coil pulsing now?
Check for pulse on all other coils.
Compare their diode mode readings with good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message:
Thanks! I'm happy to be here. 

I've taken a look at the board for any abnormality and I couldn't find it. 

5V pulses while only on USB-C power cable yes..

I totally forgot about this board that I have, I compared the diode readings on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> and it was 0.195; meaning this is normal. ðŸ˜”

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message: <SIGNAL>P5VS4_PGOOD</SIGNAL> gets high for very little 200 mv then drops..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message: Noticed a line "<SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>" that's not in the schematic but it shows it's derived from <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>; I checked for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and it's pulsing as well.. could this be the issue source?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message:
Under the thermal camera it shows the CD32115B00 is at 32C.. [S]but the device is showing 20V normally.. could it be a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> issues?![/S]

After looking at the other side of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> is where a memory module is at and next to it the camera chip and pulsing..

[URL unfurl="true"]https://file.io/yDnXHGVtcEQz[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message:
Did you check other coils for pulse?
L7900/60, L7290, L800/20/50, L8130 for example?

Also check for any output short on page 50.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message:
L7900 thereâ€™s pulse

L7960 thereâ€™s pulse

L7290 thereâ€™s pulse

L7960 (PPVCCIO) is pulsing

L8000 1.0V (<SIGNAL>PP1V_SUS</SIGNAL> present)

L8020 1.8V (<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SUS</SIGNAL> present)

L8050 1.0V (<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SUS_PCH</SIGNAL>)

L8130 no pulse; diode mode is 0.344 while on the known-good is 0.481

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message:
I have checked all SMC outputs in the page 50 and found no shorts. 
* I have checked all points expect for "NC" or under the chip points

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message:
CPU core (L7210) pulsing too?

Test if starts in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message:
No pulse on L7210.

SMC bypass mode; unsuccessful

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message:
I still suspect mechanical damage on the board.

Still pulsing with both charger and battery connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message:
Suspecting mechanical damage is very sensible especially because the tech who worked on this board its kinda his MO. 

I looked over the board again (and I will keep looking) and I found two things: bits of foam around some parts on board, that foam is under the USB-C connector on board and it's copper/gold like; IDK if its conducting or not. 
And the other thing is a little teeny bit of crack on BIOS chips.. I don't know if it's a valid suspect; picture below. 

Yes, pulse is there on battery only too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message: Yes it's conductive.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message:
Replace BIOS chip and test again.
Flash with known good BIOS, clean ME.
If no chip available, check at least if you can read/write the original.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message:
Having troubles reading off of the chip; its pretty annoying to install on reader PCB. How likely this is a BIOS issue?

I've put another BIOS chip from 00045 for the differential diagnosis purposes, and it's still behaving the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message:
Original chip has broken corner.
So is normal to suspect about its integrity.

There must be something else damaged when screen and battery have been changed.
Are you working with the board alone on the desk?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message: No I have the board with other computers and stuff.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 99671, member: 682"]
Original chip has broken corner.
So is normal to suspect about its integrity.
[/QUOTE]

Its integrity indeed in question but I would like to know if this is a suspect for such case..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message:
I reballed the original BIOS chip.. I noticed that exactly where the small crack is a trace for 3v3 pin.. It occurred to me to start measuring for diode mode under the chip and have an idea of the connectivity but right before I started measuring the chipped corner sadly couldn't handle anymore and fell off..
I measured anyway and 3.3v is OL under the chip there's no connectivity.. Wish I measured before it cracked off..

I really don't know if this is 100% BIOS or not.. ðŸ˜”

edit: before the small chip fell off it was flapping like little a thin wire hanging in there.. so IDK if the trace was already missing. picture below

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> refuses to power on
threads.message:
"No I have the board with other computers and stuff."
Not sure what this means.
I just asked if you are testing the board on the desk, without any cable connected; apart of USB-C/power flex.

You've said to have another chip; just write correct BIOS on it.

can you help me with the bios file? Im not too savvy with the bios stuff.
